I first got this game a few years ago maybe 3 years. I enjoyed it's amazing graphic design. It had a vast amount of colors making it seem like the characters themselves would light up the area. The game itself played smoothly. Worth the money. This was when i had an iPod 5. I have now upgraded to an iPhone 6s. Now, i don't know if it's the systems updates causing it but, there's no music... The music. I don't recall the way it sounded but that alone makes me not want to play the game. The music added so much to the experience I feel. It's a shame because I really wanted to play it again... I don't see myself enjoying the game until this problem is resolved. 

Good game though.

One of (if not) the best constructed and thoughtfully made games I've experience in my last three years of exploring apps on the AppStore. 

At times I almost forget I'm playing on my phone.  

I purchased this game because of my interest in NMS and wanted to experience hellogames work first hand.   

Playing Joe Danger has filled me with optimism for this small Indy studios ambitious and unique upcoming release of NoMansSky.

This is a wonderful game thoughtfully built and easy to pick up but difficult to master.  

To me it's obvious from the moment I began playing JD that the individuals that made this game love gaming. 

This game is a ray of hope that stands apart from a sea of mediocrity.

title.label: Great Game/No Support for big prob easy fix

content.label: Love the game except for one huge glaring issue that should be an easy fix. The developer has abandoned the game and provided no updates or support since September of 2014 and now with the current  iOS version the music no longer plays. I have emailed the developers and have received no response. I am sure it would be an easy fix.  Maybe Apple needs to do a better job at keeping the App Store more up to date and after sending developers a notice and deadline to update their apps, yank them from the store until they comply. Of course previous buyers would be able to always access the game in there purchase history.
please fix
Great game from a great developer. A couple it's here and there, but nothing game breaking. Can't wait for June 2016 for No Man's Sky!

title.label: I love this colorful video game!!!

content.label:
Thanks HelloGames for bringing me back to when I was 8! :D This game is pure joy for all ages, and add on Hours upon hours of Solid replay value, and you have yourself one super fun, and ADDICTING game. And just to be clear, this is a game...... Reminds me so much of Nintendo!!! and I love that! 

And the  music is  just sweet, albeit, it's a bit of a short and repetitive soundtrack , but that's alright. The few songs are plenty enough to make the experience lasting.  So to cap it off, Joe Danger Touch, and more so, Joe Danger Infinity, are my favorite IOS games. :D

Just pure fun and laughs for all ages. Now how cool is that? You guys/girls at HelloGames are awesome!
Fun

Excitebike meets Tony Hawk. Great art, audio, graphics, and especially the controls. Maybe more environments would have been great, but it is still so fun that I got 100% of all medals and trophies. Must buy for all iOS users in my opinion.
This is so addictive and fun!!
This game is pretty fun. Even for an adult. Come on you know you want to try it.

This game features all the worst tendencies of a commercial game studio releasing iOS games in 2013: unnecessary gatekeeping, convoluted menus, information overload, mindless, repetitive, marginally "fun" gameplay, and several IAPs for a game that already cost you money (to the studio's credit, the IAPs actually feel optional).

If you see the screenshots and think this looks like Excitebike, don't be fooled. The game mostly requires you to tap things. Tap to jump (there's a delay) at specified times, tap the starting block to start, tap floating letters, tap obstacles to make them disappear. Sometimes you swipe, eg you swipe to duck and to do a wheelie or flip.

You won't have freedom of movement, though. You don't swipe to move into other lanes. You don't find new ways around the track. You don't try for cool jumps. This is the IV drip gaming we've come to expect from commercial studios: bite-sized levels that shuffle and reshuffle a few basic components and bite-sized upgrades. It won't occur to you that you're not having fun.

Tap tap tap tap.
One of, if not the, best games on the entire AppStore! So much fun, addictive, and challenging!

This game like many other games and applications, starts off with the ever obnoxious pop up stating "Do You Want To Accept Push Notifications", or something to that effect.

Like always, I immediately hit the "No" or "Cancel" or "Decline" button, I cannot remember exactly what it offers at the moment, but the point being that I always flat out deny Push Notifications in any and all applications that I have installed on my iPad 4.

But, does my choice matter to this unethical and shady developer?  No, no it doesn't.  This is ever so evident by the anger-inducing fact that on three occasions now I have been greeted by my iPad upon turning it on, with stupid "Come Play Joe Danger" Push Notifications.  What this means, of course, is that this developer and many like him.  Intentionally program and code their application's so that no matter which choice the user makes pertaining to whether they Do or Do Not want to accept Push Notifications from said app.  Well, they intentionally rig their app's so that you are going to receive these annoying notifications, regardless of whether you chose to decline them or not.

I would be willing to bet too, that engineering your application to override a user's choice in regards to Push Notifications, is very much against the contract and policies that you agree to with Apple, when you sell your application's on the App Store.  So it is so very apparent that this developer and many others just could not care less about rules, guidelines, ethics and most of all, user choice relating to Push Notifications. I find it truly abhorrent that big name developers like this, are allowed to perpetrate such shady and unethical practices such as this, and I will definitely not be further supporting these crooked schemes by continuing to support these developers with my money.  You might get away with this trash for right now, but you will not see another penny from me in your future.

I have this game for the PS3 and its sequel and love them both.  This really was built for the touch screen and it really shows. This is how games should be ported to mobile devices. Well worth the .99 cents I paid for it.
